semantic_title: POA Reporting Options, Definitions, and Timeframe Guidelines
section_path: Appendix I > Present on Admission Reporting Guidelines > Reporting Options and Definitions

content.full_text: Reporting Options: Y – Yes, N – No, U – Unknown, W – Clinically undetermined, Unreported/Not used – (Exempt from POA reporting). Reporting Definitions: Y = present at the time of inpatient admission, N = not present at the time of inpatient admission, U = documentation is insufficient to determine if condition is present on admission, W = provider is unable to clinically determine whether condition was present on admission or not. Timeframe for POA Identification and Documentation: There is no required timeframe as to when a provider (per the definition of "provider" used in these guidelines) must identify or document a condition to be present on admission. In some clinical situations, it may not be possible for a provider to make a definitive diagnosis (or a condition may not be recognized or reported by the patient) for a period of time after admission. In some cases, it may be several days before the provider arrives at a definitive diagnosis. This does not mean that the condition was not present on admission. Determination of whether the condition was present on admission or not will be based on the applicable POA guideline as identified in this document, or on the provider's best clinical judgment. If at the time of code assignment the documentation is unclear as to whether a condition was present on admission or not, it is appropriate to query the provider for clarification. (Evidence: pg no: 117, L59-L68)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use Y indicator when condition present at time of inpatient admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L64)
detailed_rules.explanation: Y indicator definitively indicates the condition was present when inpatient admission occurred (Evidence: pg no: 117, L64)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use N indicator when condition not present at time of inpatient admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L65)
detailed_rules.explanation: N indicator definitively indicates the condition was not present when inpatient admission occurred (Evidence: pg no: 117, L65)
detailed_rules.applies_to: conditions clearly not present on admission

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use U indicator when documentation insufficient to determine POA status (Evidence: pg no: 117, L66)
detailed_rules.explanation: U indicator used when available documentation does not provide enough information to determine POA status (Evidence: pg no: 117, L66)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use W indicator when provider unable to clinically determine POA status (Evidence: pg no: 117, L66)
detailed_rules.explanation: W indicator used when provider cannot clinically determine whether condition was present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L66)

detailed_rules.rule_text: No required timeframe for provider to identify or document POA conditions (Evidence: pg no: 117, L67)
detailed_rules.explanation: Providers are not bound by specific timeframes to identify or document conditions as present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L67)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Delayed diagnosis does not mean condition was not present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L67-L68)
detailed_rules.explanation: The fact that a diagnosis is made days after admission does not automatically mean the condition was not present on admission (Evidence: pg no: 117, L67-L68)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Review available documentation for POA determination
Step 2: Apply appropriate POA indicator based on evidence
Step 3: Use Y if clearly present on admission
Step 4: Use N if clearly not present on admission
Step 5: Use U if documentation insufficient
Step 6: Use W if provider cannot clinically determine
Step 7: Query provider if documentation unclear
